snippet: As the E.U. grapples with a migration crisis, the resulting revival of stops at frontiers on vital transport routes threatens to cost billions in lost business.
abstract: Revival of checkpoints on some of Europe's most trafficked transit routes due to migration crisis is causing delays, impeding commerce and threatening to cost billions of euros in lost business, as continent continues to recover from six-year economic slump; critics worry that checkpoints spell permanent end to so-called Schengen Agreement, which allowed free movement of people and products between countries and helped turn European Union into economic powerhouse.

byline.original: By LIZ ALDERMAN and JAMES KANTER
byline.contributor: Liz Alderman reported from Freilassing, Germany, and James Kanter from Aalsmeer, the Netherlands. Katarina Johannsen contributed reporting from Germany and Christina Anderson from Sweden.

lead_paragraph: As the E.U. grapples with a migration crisis, the resulting revival of stops at frontiers on vital transport routes threatens to cost billions in lost business.

headline.main: Europe’s Border Checks Become Economic Choke Points
headline.print_headline: Border Checks Take Toll on Europe

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
